Acupuncture for Cancer Treatment Acupuncture is a traditional Chinese medicine technique that has been used for thousands of years to promote healing and improve overall well-being. The practice involves the insertion of thin needles into specific points on the body, called acupoints. It is believed that these acupoints correspond to pathways, or meridians, through which the body's energy, or qi, flows. By stimulating these acupoints, practitioners of acupuncture aim to balance the flow of qi and promote healing. Acupuncture has been found to be effective in managing a wide range of cancer-related symptoms, including pain, nausea, and fatigue. Pain Management: Cancer and its treatment can cause a wide range of pain, including bone pain, neuropathic pain, and pain related to surgery. Research has shown that acupuncture can be effective in reducing cancer-related pain. One study found that acupuncture was effective in reducing pain and improving function in cancer patients with bone pain. Another study found that acupuncture was effective in reducing pain and improving quality of life in cancer patients with neuropathic pain. Nausea and Vomiting: Nausea and vomiting are common side effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Research has shown that acupuncture can be effective in reducing these symptoms. One study found that acupuncture was effective in reducing nausea and vomiting in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy. Another study found that acupuncture was effective in reducing nausea in cancer patients receiving radiation therapy. Fatigue: Fatigue is a common side effect of cancer and its treatment. Research has shown that acupuncture can be effective in reducing fatigue in cancer patients. One study found that acupuncture was effective in reducing fatigue in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy. Another study found that acupuncture was effective in reducing fatigue in cancer patients with advanced cancer. Acupuncture is considered to be a safe and well-tolerated complementary therapy for cancer patients. However, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional before starting an acupuncture regimen. This is particularly important for cancer patients, as acupuncture may interact with certain cancer treatments or have other negative side effects.
